summary: This is a Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) memorandum providing a status update on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) response to recommendations from a June 2023 OIG report concerning the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's progress on eight policy and procedural recommendations aimed at preventing future incidents.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody, care, and supervision at the Metropolitan Correctional Center was the subject of the original OIG investigation that prompted these recommendations.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issued its final report investigating the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update to OIG
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons provided a status update to the OIG on its actions in response to the eight recommendations from the 2023 report.

events.title: BOP Reduces Staffing Incentives
events.description: The BOP implemented significant reductions and eliminations of retention incentives agencywide due to budgetary constraints, reversing a previous strategy to address staffing shortages.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's 2023 investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death resulted in eight specific policy recommendations for the BOP, one of which (Recommendation 7) is already closed.

The BOP is in the process of revising multiple Program Statements (5321.09, 5324.08, 5500.14, 5500.15, 4200.12) to address deficiencies in cellmate assignment, suicide prevention, inmate monitoring, and security camera systems.
Despite finding that staffing incentives improved employee retention rates from 83.5% to 88.1%, the BOP eliminated most incentives in March 2025 due to budget constraints.
All remaining recommendations are currently marked as 'Resolved' by the OIG, but final closure is pending BOP completion of policy revisions and submission of finalized documents for OIG review.
The document reveals systemic BOP policy weaknesses related to inmate supervision post-suicide watch, accountability for security rounds, and functionality checks for security camera systems.
